posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
Hi

I’m trying to implement a trapezoidal profile for our elevator, but I’m concerned that my lack of understanding of how everything “works” physics-wise will prevent me from implementing it successfully.

From what I understand, to get to a certain velocity setpoint, we calculate the feedforward necessary, which accounts for the weight of the elevator. Therefore, if we are trying to go down slowly, the feedforward equation would result in a voltage that is actually trying to move the elevator upwards (but gravity is stronger so it moves down). But if our motor is on brake mode, won’t this not work? i.e. isn’t the whole idea of brake mode that if we turn the motor a certain direction at a certain velocity, brake mode will oppose anything trying to change that direction and velocity (so our motor won’t allow the elevator to move downwards if we are trying to move the elevator upwards)?

Also, when we get close enough to our setpoint, do we just keep applying a voltage about equivalent to our gravity feedforward term to stay in the same place, or can we just call motor.stop() since we are using krakens, and let brake mode keep us in the same position with a lower power consumption?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Brake mode doesn’t oppose the motor’s force ; It opposes the motor being back-driven by gravity and inertia. So it will not interfere with your control of the elevator.

What brake mode does in a physics sense is it converts the motor’s back-driving forces (gravity) into an electrical force in the motor; In brake mode, the wire coils are passively connected such that this generates an oppositional magnetic force, causing a slowdown. It’s working as a generator, and automatically using that power to resist the motion. When the motor controller is applying it’s own motive force, the motor coils are directly connected to the battery, and thus actively powered in a desired direction with a driven magnetic field. Any “backdrive” forces are being completely overridden, or dumped into the battery as a voltage spike.

As for the feed forward, you would want to apply it at all times, even when “idle”. If your system is geared such that brake mode mostly halts the motor when disabled/stopped, then this power needed will be small. If your system is geared such that the elevator falls quickly when disabled… then you definitely want the feed forward applied at idle. I’m not familiar with CTRE specific details here though, but I’d assume “stop” causes it to halt all output, rather than maintaining the configured forward.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: So what you’re saying is that there isn’t really a difference between coast and brake when the motor is act running, bcs the whole oppositional magnetic force is overriden by the motor controller trying to control the motor? And this means that even if we run a motor in one direction (upwards), if the torque on it from the elevator is greater, it will move down and not show any weird skipping behavior?

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
GronkBaby:

there isn’t really a difference between coast and brake when the motor is act running

Correct, hence the term sometimes used: “neutral mode”  Brake and Coast only affect the motor when the control request is “apply a duty cycle of 0”  If you were using a brushed motor, like a CIM , coast would mean “connect the two wires to nothing” and brake would mean “connect the two wires together”.

GronkBaby:

And this means that even if we run a motor in one direction (upwards), if the torque on it from the elevator is greater, it will move down and not show any weird skipping behavior?

It’s worth looking at the permanent magnet motor feedforward docs.

The short of it is: when you have an elevator, you’re almost always going to apply some positive voltage to the motor to keep it from dropping; it’s pretty rare that you’ll end up braking or coasting anyway.  This is because even brake mode can’t apply any stopping force unless the elevator is moving – look up Eddy Current Braking or Magnetic Braking if you’re curious about why.

Also, if you do happen to pass through the zero duty cycle point (neutral mode) while you’re commanding the elevator to move downward, you’d want the motor to behave as though it were in brake mode anyway – apply zero volts to it – because it matches the same electrical model as when you’re connected to the battery anyway.  The motor controller, most abstractly, is trying to behave as a variable voltage source.  If you go for a slightly higher-fidelity model (look up “buck converter” if you want an interesting rabbithole), it’s trying to behave as a pulsed voltage source, variable duty cycle, or “connect leads to battery some of the time; connect them to each other the rest of the time”.  So, when the duty cycle hits 0, it’s just connecting the leads together all of the time and to the battery none of the time.

Incidentally, this is also the behavior you want when the robot gets disabled, lest the elevator free fall and slam into its bottom stop at high speed.

link_counts.title: Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
But when we are at a duty-cycle output of 0 and are in brake mode, doesn’t the motor resist all motion and the elevator would just stop? Does it make a difference that I am using MotionMagic?

Sorry about all of the questions, there isn’t really anyone I can ask on my team about this ha ha

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Yep. The motor will command it exactly as intended, and you won’t have stutters or anything of that sort. If you do have skipping or stuttering, that’s probably a belt, chain or other issue. Or a code one, such as setting the motor output to different values in a single loop.

GronkBaby:

But when we are at a duty-cycle output of 0 and are in brake mode, doesn’t the motor resist all motion and the elevator would just stop? Does it make a difference that I am using MotionMagic?

Yesn’t. When you stop() the motor and set no output, you’re not telling the motor to “stay where it is”, you’re saying “do whatever the external environment says, minus the motor’s brake resistance”. What this means is that you’re letting the physics of the system decide where things end up. This means gravity and the gear ratio control the end result, and may result in the elevator simply falling down. Or staying put. Your system will do what it’s going to do.

If you apply a feed forward, but no other output, then you’re actively telling the motor to oppose gravity. Which is probably what you want. In most cases, during operation, you want the robot to oppose both gravity (feedforwards) and sudden disturbances or external factors (the closed loop / PID ).

When the robot is disabled, now you cannot command the motor, and so brake mode or coast mode is the only thing affecting the elevator.

usbcd36:

Also, if you do happen to pass through the zero duty cycle point (neutral mode) while you’re commanding the elevator to move downward, you’d want the motor to behave as though it were in brake mode anyway

To clarify what he means here: Zero crossing is the momentary swap between forward output (going up, with an output of >0) and reverse output (going down with an output <0). While unlikely to happen mathematically, it could , and represents a moment in time when the motor controller would drop to brake mode, and be the only force acting on the elevator. However, if you consider the physics and what you’re doing, that’s fine; You’re expecting positive output one moment prior, zero this one, and negative the next. The output and the elevator are all in agreement. It’s more likely you go from value>0 to value<0 and not actually hit zero perfectly.

This is different from a prolonged session of “sit in brake mode for seconds at a time”, in which you’ve explicitly waived any actual control of the bot.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
GronkBaby:

Does it make a difference that I am using MotionMagic?

With MotionMagic, setting a reference is telling the motor “go here and stay here”, and it will run all the math and adjustments to make that happen.

“motor.stop()” is just telling the motor to let nature take it’s course, and what happens happens.

Generally, you do not want to tell a closed loop system like Motion Magic to stop functioning to let nature take the reins, and just let it stay in closed loop mode and do it’s thing.

Probably the only exception I can think of is flywheel systems; In that case, you’re either spinning up to and maintain a target RPM , or you’re done and no longer care about the RPM . In that case, “stop” makes sense, and lets the motor coast to a rest until it’s needed again.
